missionDescription: Design a concrete, testable plan for developing and validating community-endorsed workflows and lightweight software/plugins that detect edition/translation provenance, variant page/paragraph numbers, and public-domain repository citations for primary-source scholarship in psychology. Produce a prioritized task breakdown (specs for checklists, metadata schema, UI/UX requirements, automated detection heuristics, and an empirical evaluation protocol including survey and audit-study designs) that can be handed to developers, archivists, and journal partners.
missionSuccessCriteria: Detailed specification document (1â€“2 pages) listing: checklist items, required metadata fields (with controlled vocabularies and provenance tags), and data model mappings to common formats (BibTeX, CSL-JSON, TEI).

Technical requirements and heuristics: clear algorithmic rules/heuristics for flagging edition/translation provenance, mapping variant page/paragraph numbers, and detecting public-domain repository citations, plus prioritized list of three lightweight plugin architectures (e.g., browser extension, Zotero plugin, Pandoc filter) with API/format inputs and outputs.

Empirical evaluation protocol: survey instruments (target populations, sample sizes, key measures), audit-study plan (sampling frame, coding scheme, interrater reliability targets), and statistical analysis plan with primary outcomes (citation accuracy, reproducibility rate, perceived ease) and success thresholds.

Implementation-ready workplan: prioritized milestones, required roles (developer, historian/archivist, UX researcher), estimated resource/time per milestone, and a risk/mitigation table for common archival and legal issues.
